seo.title: FX Spot vs FX Forward Transactions: What's The Difference?
seo.description: Buying one currency and selling another at a fixed price is a Fx spot transactions. If settlement exceeds 2 working days, it's classified as a Forward.
seo.name: FXGuard - FX Spot and FX Forward

content: A spot foreign exchange transaction involves the purchase of one currency against the sale of another at an agreed price for delivery on a value date that is usually the trade date plus two working days. There are some exceptions, such as USD/CAD, USD/TRY, USD/PHP, USD/RUB and offshore USD/KZT and USD/PKR pairs which settle at trade date plus 1 working day.

You may also be able to settle the trade same day subject to the currency pair and cut-off times, and agreed price. Generally speaking, any Spot trade that settles in longer than 2 working days is regarded as a Forward.

The biggest advantage of an FX spot contract is its simplicity as it allows for a near immediate exchange of currencies at an agreed rate. However, Spot trading is also very restrictive for future expected receivables and payables in foreign currencies simply because these payments are to be expected and paid in future. The FX risks on future payments in foreign currencies can be better managed with FX Forward contracts.

Forward Contracts lock in exchange rates and protect you against volatility in foreign currency markets. This allows you to fix exchange rates for the purchase of currency at a future date, or over a range of dates, up to 12 months into the future. A margin deposit may be required, depending on many factors including credit risk of your company, currency pair involved, maturity of contract, and market volatility.

The agreed upon forward rate in foreign exchange contracts is usually linked to interest rate differentials between the currencies involved. The so-called Forward curve (which is expectation of a future Forward rate for different tenors) can be upward or downward sloping. For example, there are cases where the 12-month forward rate would be better than the current spot rate (this would mean benefit) and there are cases where the 12-month forward rate would be worse (this would mean cost).

A Forward contract is a simple hedging instrument that could be suited when there is a certainty about the date and amounts of future expected payments, or receivables in foreign currency. The Forward contract can be entered into without any up-front costs (margin deposits may apply). The disadvantage of FX Forward is potential opportunity cost in case of a favourable movement in the currency pair in the future.

We can send major currencies anywhere in the world where the beneficiary has a receiving account in that currency. You can use ACH or SEPA for relatively less urgent, or smaller payments. You can access SWIFT through us for faster pay-out. You will pay only one known charge for sending money with no hidden fees.
